description:
Sagmatias obliquidens, commonly known as the short-beaked common dolphin, is a species of dolphin belonging to the family Delphinidae. It is found in the temperate and tropical waters of the Pacific, Atlantic, and Indian Oceans.

The Sagmatias obliquidens is a medium-sized dolphin, typically measuring between 1.7 to 2.3 meters in length and weighing around 80 to 150 kilograms. It has a distinctive hourglass-shaped color pattern on its body, with a gray back, white belly, and a dark side stripe that extends from the eye to the tail.

This species is known for its social and acrobatic behavior, often seen swimming in large pods and performing impressive aerial displays. They are opportunistic feeders, primarily consuming small schooling fish, squid, and crustaceans.

Sagmatias obliquidens is considered a relatively common and widespread species, and it is classified as Least Concern on the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. However, like many marine mammals, it faces threats from human activities such as bycatch in fisheries, pollution, and habitat degradation.
